   35 yo M with PMH of CP, seizure disorder, GIB, pancreatic cyst s/p
   drainage in [**2113**], admitted with abdominal pain with complicated course,
   now with new fever, tachypnea, and hypoxia.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:   Patient transferred to MICU with tachypnea and
   hypoxia on [**2115-3-23**] and intubated on [**2115-3-24**].  Given his new fever,
   respiratory deterioration, and imaging findings consistent with
   multilobar pneumonia he was started on vancomycin, cefepime and flagyl
   (concern for aspiration given recently started tube feeds).  Sputum
   growing MRSA.  Pleural effusions also noted on imaging, likely due to
   fluid resuscitation for hypotension in the setting of albumin of 2.3,
   so over the past 24 hours have been diuresing with lasix boluses.  PE
   considered but CTA negative.   Few apneic episodes two nights ago may
   be secondary to aggressive diuresis.  Extubated yesterday; has had a
   few low O2 sats.
   - Completed 8-day course of vanc, cefepime, metronidazole
   - continue with daily RSBI and SBT as tolerated, likely will extubate
   today
   - follow ABGs
   - [**Hospital1 **] electrolytes with repletion while on Lasix
   - f/u blood cultures
   - morphine for grunting/resp distress x 1 to see if helpful
   .
   # Fever/sepsis: Pt febrile with tachycardia and tachypnea; meets
   definition of sepsis with most likely source being pulmonary (MRSA).
   With ascites, SBP is also possible although he is now s/p 3 taps which
   have not been c/w SBP. Urinalysis and culture from [**3-23**] with staph spp
   but repeat appears clean with NGTD.  MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 4578**] with no obvious
   nuchal rigidity although exam limited by pt cooperation.  Again, PE
   could cause similar sx of fever and respiratory distress but none seen
   on CTA. Continues febrile daily. No further episodes of AMS. CT read as
   possible liver abscess but repeat RUQ ultrasound read as more
   consistent with infarct.  C. Diff has been negative.  Continues to have
   fever to 101 on [**2-24**] overnight but normal white count, lactate normal.
   - Off Abx as above.
   - Goal CVP 8-12 but no measurements available currently
 will bolus
   for tachycardia, UOP < 30cc/h, goal MAP >60, CvO2 >70
   - Pressors for MAP > 55-60, off vasopressors
   - Monitor mental status
   - Consider paracentesis if continues febrile and no other source (would
   likely need to be done by IR)
   .
   #Hypotension. MAP goal > 60. No further episodes of AMS since starting
   pressors on [**3-25**]. Not on vasopressors.
   # Tachycardia: Likely hyperdynamic in setting of fever, infection.
   Volume status appears grossly euvolemic; pt mentating at [**Month/Year (2) 4578**] and

   hemorrhage into bowel wall, also gastric varices c/b GIB earlier in
   admission. Transfused 1 unit pRBCs [**3-25**] with appropriate bump and has
   remained stable since.
   - Trend Hct
   - Guaiac stools
   - Active T&S
   - continue pantoprazole 40mg IV bid
   - Continue iron supplement
   # Liver lesion. Noted on abdominal CT. Possible ischemia/infarction vs
   abscess. Abdominal U/S [**3-27**] not consistent with abscess.
   # Left humeral fx: Likely d/t trauma sustained during radiology.
   - No surgical indication at this time
   - Pain control with lidoderm patch and morphine prn
   .
   # SMV thrombus: Plan for anticoagulation x 6 months but held in setting
   of recent GI and RP bleed.
   - Continue heparin SQ
   .
   # Seizure disorder: No recent reports of seizures. Caution as certain
   antibiotics may lower seizure threshold.
   - Continue phenobarbitol and phenytoin
   - drug levels stable as of [**3-31**]
   .
   # Cerebral palsy: Stable mental status.  Interactive with family but
   nonverbal at [**Date Range 4578**].
   .
   FEN: NG tube likely in duodenum, bolus IVF prn, TPN; continue tube
   feeds today
   PROPHYLAXIS: pneumoboots, IV PPI
   ACCESS: PICC, PIV, D/C A-line in right brachial artery

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 35-year-old male with a medical history of chronic pancreatitis, seizure disorder, gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), and pancreatic cyst that was drained in [**2113**]. The patient was admitted with abdominal pain and later developed respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation.

The patient has had a complicated course, including new fever, tachypnea, and hypoxia. Imaging findings are consistent with multilobar pneumonia, and the patient was started on vancomycin, cefepime, and metronidazole due to concerns for aspiration given recently started tube feeds. Sputum cultures grew methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Pleural effusions were also noted on imaging, likely due to fluid resuscitation for hypotension.

The patient has been diuresing with Lasix boluses and has experienced hypotension with MAPs in the 70s. The patient's blood pressure improved to the 90s after giving a 250cc bolus. Overnight, the patient experienced a drop in mean arterial pressure (MAP) to 55 and systolic blood pressure (SBP) to <70, so a 250cc bolus was given.

The patient's recent labs show a white blood cell count (WBC) of 10.7, hemoglobin (Hct) of 30.4, platelet count (Plt) of 37,000, creatinine (Cr) of 0.6, blood glucose of 118, and electrolyte imbalances. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) values indicate respiratory alkalosis with a pH of 7.49.

Assessment and plan:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient was transferred to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) with tachypnea and hypoxia on [**2115-3-23**] and intubated on [**2115-3-24**]. The patient has been treated with vancomycin, cefepime, and metronidazole for MRSA pneumonia. The patient's sputum culture is negative. The patient is expected to continue with daily respiratory system baseline assessment (RSBI) and spontaneous breathing trials (SBT) as tolerated and will likely be extubated today.

2. Fever/sepsis: The patient remains febrile with tachycardia and tachypnea, meeting the definition of sepsis with the most likely source being pulmonary (MRSA). The patient's blood cultures are negative. SBP is also possible, although the patient has already undergone three taps without finding any signs of SBP. Urinalysis and culture from [**3-23**] showed staph spp., but the repeat culture appears clean with no growth of nitrate-reducing gram-negative bacteria (NGTD).

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 35-year-old male with a history of cerebral palsy, seizure disorder, gastrointestinal bleeding, pancreatic cyst, and previous hospitalization for abdominal pain. He was admitted with respiratory failure and intubated on day 2. The patient developed a fever, tachypnea, and hypoxia, leading to the initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics (vancomycin, cefepime, and metronidazole) due to suspected pneumonia and concern for aspiration. His sputum grew MRSA, and pleural effusions were noted on imaging. The patient has been diuresing with Lasix boluses due to fluid overload. He was extubated yesterday but experienced low O2 sats. The patient is still febrile and tachycardic. He has a history of ascites with three prior paracenteses without detection of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). Urinalysis and culture showed staph spp but repeated tests were clean with no growth of nitrate-reducing bacteria. A possible liver abscess was seen on CT scan, but it was read as more consistent with infarction. Clostridium difficile was negative. The patient continues to have fever, tachycardia, and hypoxia despite being off antibiotics. The assessment includes respiratory failure, fever/sepsis, hypotension, tachycardia, anemia/bleed, liver lesion,

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 35-year-old male with a history of cerebral palsy, seizure disorder, gastrointestinal bleeding, pancreatic cyst, and a recent episode of respiratory failure. He was admitted with abdominal pain and developed a complicated course, including fever, tachypnea, and hypoxia. The patient was transferred to the MICU and intubated due to respiratory distress. Imaging findings consistent with multilobar pneumonia were observed, leading to the initiation of vancomycin, cefepime, and metronidazole (concern for aspiration given recently started tube feeds). Sputum cultures grew MRSA. Pleural effusions were also noted on imaging, likely due to fluid resuscitation. The patient has been diuresed with Lasix boluses. A CT angiogram (CTA) was negative for pulmonary embolism. The patient was extubated on 3/30 but subsequently developed respiratory distress, likely due to mucous plugging and secretions with rhonchorous breath sounds on examination. Pulmonary edema may also be contributing. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's current respiratory distress could lead to further respiratory failure if not properly managed.
2. Sepsis: The patient meets the definition of sepsis with fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea, likely originating from a pulmonary source (MRSA pneumonia).

Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU for sepsis secondary to pneumonia with acute kidney injury. The patient's medical history includes coronary artery disease, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He has no known drug allergies.

The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature of 38.2 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 116 beats per minute, blood pressure of 83/63 mmHg, respiratory rate of 39 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on a nasal cannula with face tent. The patient is receiving supplemental oxygen.

The patient has been started on fluconazole 6mg/kg for a yeast infection, which was identified in both the blood culture (3-31) and urine culture (3-29). The Foley catheter has been changed, and daily blood cultures are being obtained. The PICC line will need to be pulled due to difficulty flushing and drawing labs. An echo and ophthalmology consult may be required.

   Assessment and Plan
   35 yo M with PMH of CP, seizure disorder, GIB, pancreatic cyst s/p
   drainage in [**2113**], admitted with abdominal pain with complicated course
   now with fever, hypoxemia, blood culture growing yeast.
   .
   # Hypoxemia:   Patient transferred to MICU with tachypnea and hypoxia
   on [**2115-3-23**] and intubated on [**2115-3-24**].  Imaging findings consistent with
   multilobar pneumonia with sputum growing MRSA, complted 8 day course of
   vanc, cefepime, and flagyl on [**2115-3-31**]. Pleural effusions also noted on
   imaging, likely due to fluid resuscitation for hypotension in the
   setting of albumin of 2.3, so have been diuresing with lasix boluses.
   Extubated on [**2115-3-30**].  The current respiratory distress is likely due
   to mucous plugging, secretions with rhonchorous breath sounds on exam.
   Pulmonary edema may also be contributing.
   - suction and light chest PT
   - continue gentle diuresis with lasix 40mg IV boluses to goal -500cc
   - change pantoprazole from IV to PO to limit amount of IVF
   - follow ABGs
   - f/u blood cultures
   - morphine for grunting/resp distress x 1 to see if helpful
   - will discuss non-invasive pressure ventilation if necessary with
   family
   .
   # Yeast bacteremia:  Patient continues to have fevers, now with
   positive urine and blood cultures growing yeast.  Possible urogenital
   source with hematogenous spread.  Heart rate and blood pressure
   currently at baseline.  Normal WBC count, lactate.
   - daily blood cultures
   - TTE
   - pull picc line and arterial line pending obtainment of new central
   access
   - start fluconazole 200 IV (6mg/kg)
   - foley catheter changed overnight
   - ophthalmologic evaluation
   - check LFT, EKG
   - f/u aspergillus, beta glucan
   .
   #Fevers:  Patient daily low grade febrile episodes despite broad
   spectrum antibiotics.  Completed treatment for pulmonary infection with
   8 day course of vancomycin, cefepime, flagyl.  SBP possible but 3 taps
   have not been c/w SBP.  PE considered but no evidence on CTA.  CT read
   as possible liver abscess but repeat RUQ ultrasound read as more
   consistent with infarct.  C. Diff has been negative.  Overnight
   positive urine and blood culture growing yeast.
   - treatment for yeast bloodstream infection as above
   -
   # Tachycardia: Likely hyperdynamic in setting of fever, infection.
   Volume status appears grossly euvolemic; pt mentating at baseline and
   maintaining urine output.  Echo with evidence of depressed cardiac fxn,
   ? tachycardia induced cardiomyopathy
   - Tylenol prn fever
   - Antimicrobial agents as above
   .
   # Anemia/bleed: Hct stable. Pt with RP bleed and CT evidence of
   hemorrhage into bowel wall, also gastric varices c/b GIB earlier in
   admission. Transfused 1 unit pRBCs [**3-25**] with appropriate bump and has
   remained stable since.
   - Trend Hct
   - Guaiac stools
   - Active T&S
   - change pantoprazole to PO
   - Continue iron supplement
   # Liver lesion. Noted on abdominal CT. Possible ischemia/infarction vs
   abscess. Abdominal U/S [**3-27**] not consistent with abscess.
   .
   # Left humeral fx: Likely d/t trauma sustained during radiology.
   - No surgical indication at this time
   - Pain control with lidoderm patch and morphine prn
   .
   # SMV thrombus: Plan for anticoagulation x 6 months but held in setting
   of recent GI and RP bleed.
   - Continue heparin SQ
   .
   # Seizure disorder: No recent reports of seizures. Caution as certain
   antibiotics may lower seizure threshold.
   - Continue phenobarbitol and phenytoin
   - drug levels stable as of [**3-31**], continue to monitor
   .
   # Cerebral palsy: Stable mental status.  Interactive with family but
   nonverbal at baseline.
   .
   FEN: continue tube feeds today
   PROPHYLAXIS: pneumoboots, PO PPI
   ACCESS: PICC, A-line in right brachial artery
   CODE: Do not resuscitate/Do not re-intubate. No CPR or defibrillation.

- Patient is a 35-year-old male with a history of cerebral palsy, seizure disorder, gastrointestinal bleeding, and pancreatic cyst.

- He was extubated on 03/30 but currently experiencing respiratory distress likely due to mucous plugging and secretions.
- The patient has positive urine and blood cultures growing yeast, suggesting a possible urogenital source with hematogenous spread.
- He is febrile despite broad-spectrum antibiotics and has low-grade febrile episodes.
- The patient's heart rate and blood pressure are at baseline with normal WBC count and lactate levels.
- He has an echocardiogram showing evidence of depressed cardiac function, possibly tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy.
- The patient has stable hemoglobin levels and has received a blood transfusion previously.
- There is a liver lesion noted on abdominal CT, possibly ischemia/infarction or abscess.
- The patient has a left humeral fracture likely due to trauma sustained during radiology.
- He has a superior mesenteric vein thrombus and is planned for anticoagulation but

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 35-year-old male with a history of cerebral palsy, seizure disorder, gastrointestinal bleeding, pancreatic cyst drainage, and multilobar pneumonia. He was admitted with abdominal pain and developed fever, hypoxemia, and blood culture growing yeast. The patient had an 8-day course of vancomycin, cefepime, and flagyl for pneumonia. He was extubated on [**2115-3-30**] but is now experiencing respiratory distress likely due to mucous plugging and pulmonary edema. The patient has positive urine and blood cultures growing yeast, indicating a yeast bacteremia. He also has a low-grade fever despite broad-spectrum antibiotics. Other conditions include tachycardia, anemia/bleed, liver lesion, left humeral fracture, and SMV thrombus. The patient has a DNR code status.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure due to mucous plugging and pulmonary edema.
2. Yeast bacteremia with possible urogenital source and hematogenous spread.
3. Hypoxemia from pneumonia and respiratory distress.
4. Tachycardia likely due to hyperdynamic state in setting of fever and infection.
5. Anemia/bleed with previous gastrointestinal bleeding and transfusion.
6. Liver lesion with possible ischemia/infarction or abscess.
7. Left humeral fracture from trauma sustained during radiology.
8. SM

   Pulmonary edema may also be contributing.

   - will discuss non-invasive pressure ventilation if necessary with
   family

   positive urine and blood cultures growing yeast.  Possible urogenital

   have not been c/w SBP.  PE considered but no evidence on CTA.  CT read
   as possible liver abscess but repeat RUQ ultrasound read as more
   consistent with infarct.  C. Diff has been negative.  Overnight
   positive urine and blood culture growing yeast.
   - treatment for yeast bloodstream infection as above
   -

   Volume status appears grossly euvolemic; pt mentating at baseline and
   maintaining urine output.  Echo with evidence of depressed cardiac fxn,
   ? tachycardia induced cardiomyopathy
   - Tylenol prn fever

   admission. Transfused 1 unit pRBCs [**3-25**] with appropriate bump and has
   remained stable since.

   # Liver lesion. Noted on abdominal CT. Possible ischemia/infarction vs
   abscess. Abdominal U/S [**3-27**] not consistent with abscess.

   # Left humeral fx: Likely d/t trauma sustained during radiology.
   - No surgical indication at this time
   - Pain control with lidoderm patch and morphine prn
   .
   # SMV thrombus: Plan for anticoagulation x 6 months but held in setting
   of recent GI and RP bleed.
   - Continue heparin SQ
   .
   # Seizure disorder: No recent reports of seizures. Caution as certain
   antibiotics may lower seizure threshold.
   - Continue phenobarbitol and phenytoin, but transition to PO route
   - check drug levels
   .
   # Cerebral palsy: Stable mental status.  Interactive with family but
   nonverbal at baseline.
   - speech and swallow evaluation
   .

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient has been admitted with a history of cerebral palsy, seizure disorder, gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), pancreatic cyst drainage, and a recent admission for abdominal pain with complications. The patient is currently in the ICU due to respiratory distress and yeast bacteremia.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the information provided include:

1. Hypoxemia: The patient has been transferred to the MICU with tachypnea and hypoxia, and later intubated. They have completed a course of antibiotics for multilobar pneumonia but continue to experience respiratory distress, possibly due to mucous plugging and secretions. Pulmonary edema may also be contributing to their respiratory issues.

2. Yeast Bacteremia: The patient has positive urine and blood cultures growing yeast, indicating a yeast bloodstream infection. This could lead to further systemic complications if not appropriately treated.

3. Tachycardia: The patient's heart rate is elevated, which could be due to hyperdynamic state in the setting of fever and infection. There is also evidence of depressed cardiac function on the echocardiogram, raising the possibility of tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy.

4. Anemia/Bleed: Although the patient's hemoglobin concentration is stable, they have a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and evidence of hemorrhage into the bowel wall. Close monitoring of hemodynamic status and appropriate management of potential bleeding episodes are necessary.

5. Liver Lesion

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 35-year-old male with a complex medical history including cerebral palsy, seizure disorder, gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), pancreatic cyst that was drained in 2013, and recent respiratory distress due to mucous plugging and secretions. The patient has been admitted multiple times with various complications such as multilobar pneumonia, pleural effusions, yeast bacteremia, liver lesion, left humeral fracture, and SMV thrombus.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Hypoxemia: The patient's respiratory distress and mucous plugging can lead to inadequate oxygenation of the blood.

2. Yeast bloodstream infection: The patient has positive blood cultures growing yeast, indicating a possible yeast bloodstream infection. This requires prompt treatment with appropriate antifungal medications.

3. Cardiac dysfunction: The echocardiogram showed moderately thickened and deformed aortic valve leaflets with moderate to severe stenosis, at least moderate mitral regurgitation, and small echodensity in the left atrium adjacent to the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve. These findings suggest potential cardiac dysfunction, which may be exacerbated by the presence of a yeast bloodstream infection.

4. Liver lesion: The patient has a liver lesion that could potentially be an abscess or ischemia/infarction. Further evaluation and monitoring are necessary to determine the cause and appropriate management.

5. SMV

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 35-year-old man with cerebral palsy who is experiencing respiratory failure and aspiration pneumonia. He has had a peritoneal dialysis catheter placed and has undergone several procedures, including arterial line insertion, paracentesis, and trans thoracic echo. The patient has a history of seizure disorder and is on medication for it. He is currently receiving multiple medications for various conditions, including antibiotics for suspected fungal infection. The patient's vital signs show tachycardia and low blood pressure, indicating potential cardiovascular compromise. His respiratory support includes oxygen delivery through a nasal cannula and face tent. The patient's ABG results show respiratory acidosis. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds at the bases of the lungs. The patient's lab results indicate leukocytosis with neutrophilia, elevated creatinine, and low albumin levels. He also has elevated liver enzymes and abnormal electrolyte levels. Fluid analysis of peritoneal fluid shows an increased white blood cell count with neutrophils.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Prolonged respiratory failure leading to hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
2. Development of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
3. Sepsis due to fungal infection or aspiration pneumonia.
4. Cardiac tamponade or other cardiac complications.
5. Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypotension or sepsis.
6. Malnutrition and poor nutritional status.
7. Deep vein thrombosis

   35 yo M with PMH of CP, seizure disorder, GIB, pancreatic cyst s/p
   drainage in [**2113**], admitted with abdominal pain with complicated course
   now with fever, hypoxemia, blood culture growing yeast.
   .
   # Hypoxemia:   Patient transferred to MICU with tachypnea and hypoxia
   on [**2115-3-23**] and intubated on [**2115-3-24**].  Imaging findings consistent with
   multilobar pneumonia with sputum growing MRSA, complted 8 day course of
   vanc, cefepime, and flagyl on [**2115-3-31**]. Pleural effusions also noted on
   imaging, likely due to fluid resuscitation for hypotension in the
   setting of albumin of 2.3, so have been diuresing with lasix boluses.
   Extubated on [**2115-3-30**].  The current respiratory distress is likely due
   to mucous plugging, secretions with rhonchorous breath sounds on exam.
   Pulmonary edema may also be contributing.
   - suction and light chest PT as tolerated
   - continue gentle diuresis with lasix 40mg IV for TBB -500ml today
   - follow ABGs
   - morphine for grunting/resp distress as needed
   - will discuss non-invasive pressure ventilation if necessary with
   family
   .
   # Yeast bacteremia:  Patient continues to have low grade fevers, now
   with positive blood cultures growing yeast.  Possible urogenital source
   with hematogenous spread.  Heart rate and blood pressure currently at
   baseline.  Normal WBC count, lactate.
   - follow fever curve
   - lines removed and replaced
   - daily blood cultures
   - follow speciation and sensitivity
   - continue micafungin IV per ID day 1 = [**4-2**]
   - f/u ID recs
   - follow LFT, EKG while on micafungin
   - f/u PICC tip culture
   - f/u aspergillus, beta glucan
   .
   #Fevers:  Patient daily low grade febrile episodes despite broad
   spectrum antibiotics.  Completed treatment for pulmonary infection with
   8 day course of vancomycin, cefepime, flagyl.  SBP possible but 3 taps
   have not been c/w SBP.  PE considered but no evidence on CTA.  CT read
   as possible liver abscess but repeat RUQ ultrasound read as more
   consistent with infarct.  C. Diff has been negative.  Overnight
   positive urine and blood culture growing yeast. Repeat cultures of
   blood, urine ngtd.
   - treatment for yeast bloodstream infection as above
   -
   # Tachycardia: Likely hyperdynamic in setting of fever, infection.
   Volume status appears grossly euvolemic; pt mentating at baseline and
   maintaining urine output.  Echo with evidence of depressed cardiac fxn,
   ? tachycardia induced cardiomyopathy
   - Tylenol prn fever
   - Antimicrobial agents as above
   .
   # Anemia/bleed: Hct stable. Pt with RP bleed and CT evidence of
   hemorrhage into bowel wall, also gastric varices c/b GIB earlier in
   admission. Transfused 1 unit pRBCs [**3-25**] with appropriate bump and has
   remained stable since.
   - Trend Hct qd
   - Guaiac stools
   - Active T&S
   - PO pantoprazole
   - Continue iron supplement
   # Liver lesion. Noted on abdominal CT. Possible ischemia/infarction vs
   abscess. Abdominal U/S [**3-27**] not consistent with abscess.
   .
   # Left humeral fx: Likely d/t trauma sustained during radiology.
   - No surgical indication at this time
   - Pain control with lidoderm patch and morphine prn
   .
   # SMV thrombus: Plan for anticoagulation x 6 months but held in setting
   of recent GI and RP bleed.
   - Continue heparin SQ
   .
   # Seizure disorder: No recent reports of seizures. Caution as certain
   antibiotics may lower seizure threshold.
   - Continue phenobarbitol and phenytoin, but transition to PO route
   - Drug levels wnl on [**4-3**]
   .
   # Cerebral palsy: Stable mental status.  Interactive with family but
   nonverbal at baseline.
   - speech and swallow evaluation: advance diet
   .
   # Case Management
 likely d/c to rehab tomorrow.
   .

   pureed solids; needs 1:1 observation (mother may need to feed). OK to
   try crushed meds, but may not take reliably

The patient is a 35-year-old male with a medical history of cerebral palsy, seizure disorder, gastrointestinal bleeding, pancreatic cyst post drainage in 2013, admitted with abdominal pain, complicated course now with fever, hypoxemia, and blood culture growing yeast. The patient was transferred to the MICU with tachypnea and hypoxia on 03/23/2015, intubated on 03/24/2015, and extubated on 03/30/2015. He has completed an 8-day course of vancomycin, cefepime, and flagyl for multilobar pneumonia with sputum growing MRSA. Pleural effusions were also noted on imaging, likely due to fluid resuscitation for hypotension in the setting of an albumin level of 2.3, so he has been diuresed with Lasix boluses. 

The patient currently has low-grade fevers, positive blood cultures growing yeast, and is being treated with micafungin IV. He has rhonchi on lung auscultation, suggesting possible mucous plugging, and may have pulmonary edema contributing to his respiratory distress. 

He has a history of anemia and bleeding, with a stable hematocrit level. The patient has been transfused 1 unit of packed red blood cells on 03/25/2015 and has remained stable since. 

There is a liver lesion noted on abdominal

   35 yo M with PMH of CP, seizure disorder, GIB, pancreatic cyst s/p
   drainage in [**2113**], admitted with abdominal pain with complicated course
   now with fever, hypoxemia, blood culture growing yeast.
   .
   # Hypoxemia:   Patient transferred to MICU with tachypnea and hypoxia
   on [**2115-3-23**] and intubated on [**2115-3-24**].  Imaging findings consistent with
   multilobar pneumonia with sputum growing MRSA, complted 8 day course of
   vanc, cefepime, and flagyl on [**2115-3-31**]. Pleural effusions also noted on
   imaging, likely due to fluid resuscitation for hypotension in the
   setting of albumin of 2.3, so have been diuresing with lasix boluses.
   Extubated on [**2115-3-30**].  The current respiratory distress is likely due
   to mucous plugging, secretions with rhonchorous breath sounds on exam.
   Pulmonary edema may also be contributing.
   - suction and light chest PT as tolerated
   - continue gentle diuresis with lasix 40mg IV boluses to go even as
   patient appears slightly dry on exam
   - follow ABGs
   - morphine for grunting/resp distress as needed
   - will discuss non-invasive pressure ventilation if necessary with
   family
   .
   # Yeast bacteremia:  Patient continues to have low grade fevers, now
   with positive blood cultures growing yeast.  Possible urogenital source
   with hematogenous spread.  Heart rate and blood pressure currently at
   baseline.  Normal WBC count, lactate.
   - follow fever curve
   - lines removed and replaced
   - daily blood cultures
   - follow speciation and sensitivity
   - continue micafungin IV per ID day 1 = [**4-2**]
   - f/u ID recs
   - follow LFT, EKG
   - f/u PICC tip culture
   - f/u aspergillus, beta glucan
   .
   #Fevers:  Patient daily low grade febrile episodes despite broad
   spectrum antibiotics.  Completed treatment for pulmonary infection with
   8 day course of vancomycin, cefepime, flagyl.  SBP possible but 3 taps
   have not been c/w SBP.  PE considered but no evidence on CTA.  CT read
   as possible liver abscess but repeat RUQ ultrasound read as more
   consistent with infarct.  C. Diff has been negative.  Overnight
   positive urine and blood culture growing yeast. Repeat cultures of
   blood, urine ngtd.
   - treatment for yeast bloodstream infection as above
   -
   # Tachycardia: Likely hyperdynamic in setting of fever, infection.
   Volume status appears grossly euvolemic; pt mentating at baseline and
   maintaining urine output.  Echo with evidence of depressed cardiac fxn,
   ? tachycardia induced cardiomyopathy
   - Tylenol prn fever
   - Antimicrobial agents as above
   .
   # Anemia/bleed: Hct stable. Pt with RP bleed and CT evidence of
   hemorrhage into bowel wall, also gastric varices c/b GIB earlier in
   admission. Transfused 1 unit pRBCs [**3-25**] with appropriate bump and has
   remained stable since.
   - Trend Hct qd
   - Guaiac stools
   - Active T&S
   - PO pantoprazole
   - Continue iron supplement
   # Liver lesion. Noted on abdominal CT. Possible ischemia/infarction vs
   abscess. Abdominal U/S [**3-27**] not consistent with abscess.
   .
   # Left humeral fx: Likely d/t trauma sustained during radiology.
   - No surgical indication at this time
   - Pain control with lidoderm patch and morphine prn
   .
   # SMV thrombus: Plan for anticoagulation x 6 months but held in setting
   of recent GI and RP bleed.
   - Continue heparin SQ???
   .

   antibiotics may lower seizure threshold.
   - Continue phenobarbitol and phenytoin, but transition to PO route
   - Drug levels wnl on [**4-3**]
   .
   # Cerebral palsy: Stable mental status.  Interactive with family but
   nonverbal at baseline.
   - speech and swallow evaluation: advance diet

Summary:
The patient is a 35-year-old male with a history of cerebral palsy, seizure disorder, gastrointestinal bleeding, pancreatic cysts, and multiple comorbidities. He was admitted with abdominal pain and developed fever, hypoxemia, and blood culture growing yeast. The patient has been treated for multilobar pneumonia with MRSA, completed an 8-day course of vancomycin, cefepime, and flagyl. He was extubated on [**2115-3-30**] and currently has respiratory distress likely due to mucous plugging and pulmonary edema. The patient has a positive blood culture growing yeast, possible urogenital source with hematogenous spread. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and hypoxemia indicate a risk of respiratory failure. Close monitoring and suctioning as tolerated are recommended.

2. Infection: The patient has a positive blood culture growing yeast, suggesting a yeast bloodstream infection. Treatment with micafungin IV is ongoing, and follow-up blood cultures are necessary.

3. Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's echocardiogram showed evidence of depressed cardiac function, possibly tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy. Monitoring of heart rate and blood pressure is essential, and further evaluation may be required.

4. Bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and received a blood transfusion. Regular monitoring of hemodynamic status and coagulation parameters
